original: Majjhima Nikāya 79
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Cūḷasakuludāyisutta
analyzed: cūḷasakuludāyisutta
translated: With Sakuludāyī

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: Once the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sakuludāyī paribbājako moranivāpe paribbājakārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sa kula udāyī paribbājakaḥ moranivāpe paribbājaka ārāme paṭivasati mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhi
translated: At that time the wanderer Sakuludāyī was staying in the wanderers’ park at the debating hall by the Sambarā rock with a large assembly of wanderers.

original: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya rājagaham piṇḍāya pāvisi
translated: Then, in the morning, the Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Rājagaha for alms.

original: Atha kho bhagavato etadahosi:
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavataḥ
translated: Then he thought,

original: “atippago kho tāva rājagahe piṇḍāya carituṁ.
analyzed: atippago kho tāva rājagahe piṇḍāya caritu
translated: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ yena moranivāpo paribbājakārāmo yena sakuludāyī paribbājako tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham yena moranivāpaḥ paribbājaka ārāmaḥ yena sakuludāyī paribbājako tena upasaṅkameyyanti
translated: Why don’t I go to the debating hall by the Sambarā rock in the wanderers’ park by the pond of the sheep sellers?”

original: Atha kho bhagavā yena moranivāpo paribbājakārāmo tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā yena moranivāpaḥ paribbājaka ārāmaḥ tena upasaṅkami
translated: And he did just that.

original: Tena kho pana samayena sakuludāyī paribbājako mahatiyā paribbājakaparisāya saddhiṁ
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena sa kula udāyī paribbājakaḥ mahatiyā paribbājaka parisāya saddhi
translated: At that time Sakuludāyī was sitting with a large assembly of wanderers who were making an uproar, loudly and noisily talking many kinds of pointless talk,

original: nisinno hoti unnādiniyā uccāsaddamahāsaddāya anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentiyā, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: nisinnaḥ hoti unnādiniyā uccāsadda mahāsaddāya aneka vihitam tiracchāna katham kathentiyā
translated: and they were making an uproar, a dreadful racket, as they discussed all kinds of unworthy topics,🔽such as stories about kings, gangsters, and government officials,

original: rājakathaṁ corakathaṁ mahāmattakathaṁ senākathaṁ bhayakathaṁ yuddhakathaṁ annakathaṁ🔽pānakathaṁ vatthakathaṁ sayanakathaṁ mālākathaṁ gandhakathaṁ ñātikathaṁ yānakathaṁ🔽gāmakathaṁ nigamakathaṁ nagarakathaṁ janapadakathaṁ itthikathaṁ sūrakathaṁ visikhākathaṁ
analyzed: rāja katham cora katham mahā matta katham senā katham bhaya katham yuddha katham anna katha  pāna katham vattha katham sayana katham mālā katham gandha katham ñāti katham yāna katha  gāma katham nigama katham nagara katham janapada katham itthi katham sūra katham visikhā katha
translated: stories about wars, battles, and battles lost,

original: kumbhaṭṭhānakathaṁ pubbapetakathaṁ nānattakathaṁ lokakkhāyikaṁ samuddakkhāyikaṁ itibhavābhavakathaṁ iti vā.
analyzed: kumbhaṭṭhāna katham pubba peta katham nānatta katham loka khāyikam samudda khāyikam iti bhava abhava katham iti vā
translated: stories about food, drink, clothes, and beds, stories about garlands and perfumes, stories about relatives, stories about boats, stories about the departed, stories about various kinds of worthless things, stories about the nether world, or they were speculating about the world and the sea, or telling stories about the origin of the world.

original: Addasā kho sakuludāyī paribbājako bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
analyzed: addasā kho sakuludāyī paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam dūratas vas āgacchanta
translated: Sakuludāyī saw the Buddha coming in the distance,

original: Disvāna sakaṁ parisaṁ saṇṭhāpesi:
analyzed: disvāna sakam parisam saṇṭhāpesi
translated: and he addressed his assembly,

original: “appasaddā bhonto hontu, mā bhonto saddamakattha.
analyzed: appasaddāḥ bhonto hontu mā bhonto saddam akattha
translated: “Be quiet, good sirs, don’t make a sound.

original: Ayaṁ samaṇo gotamo āgacchati;
analyzed: ayam samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ āgacchati
translated: Here comes the ascetic Gotama.

original: appasaddakāmo kho pana so āyasmā appasaddassa vaṇṇavādī.
analyzed: appasadda kāmaḥ kho pana so āyasmat appasaddassa vaṇṇa vādī
translated: He is one who likes quiet and speaks in praise of quiet.

original: Appeva nāma appasaddaṁ parisaṁ viditvā upasaṅkamitabbaṁ maññeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma appa saddam parisam viditvā upasaṅkamitabbam maññeyya ati
translated: Perhaps he will think it is the right time to come to see me when he knows that the assembly is quiet.”

original: Atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesuṁ.
analyzed: atha kho te paribbājakā tuṇhī ahesu
translated: The wanderers fell silent.

original: Atha kho bhagavā yena sakuludāyī paribbājako tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā yena sa kula udāyī paribbājakaḥ tena upasaṅkami
translated: Then the Buddha went to the wanderer Sakuludāyī.

original: Atha kho sakuludāyī paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sa kula udāyī paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Sakuludāyī said to him,

original: “etu kho, bhante, bhagavā.
analyzed: etu kho bhante bhagavā
translated: “Please come in, Blessed One.

original: Svāgataṁ, bhante, bhagavato.
analyzed: svāgata bhante bhagavato
translated: Welcome, Blessed One.

original: Cirassaṁ kho, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ pariyāyamakāsi yadidaṁ idhāgamanāya.
analyzed: cirassam kho bhante bhagavā imam pariyāyam akāsi yat idam idha āgamanāya
translated: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.

original: Nisīdatu, bhante, bhagavā;
analyzed: nisīdatu bhante bhagavā
translated: Please, Blessed One, sit down.

original: idamāsanaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: idam āsanam paññattanti
translated: This seat is ready.”

original: Nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane.
analyzed: nisīdi bhagavā paññatte āsane
translated: The Buddha sat down on the seat prepared for him.

original: Sakuludāyīpi kho paribbājako aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: sakuludāyī ipi kho paribbājakaḥ aññataram nīcam āsanam gahetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Sakuludāyī took a low seat, sat down to one side,

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnam kho sakuludāyim paribbājakam bhagavān etat avoca
translated: and said to the Buddha,

original: “kāya nuttha, udāyi, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha udāyi etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “What were you sitting talking about just now, Udayin? What conversation was unfinished when I arrived?”

original: “Tiṭṭhatesā, bhante, kathā yāya mayaṁ etarahi kathāya sannisinnā.
analyzed: tiṭṭhate isā bhante kathā yāya mayam etarahi kathāya sannisinnā
translated: “Let be, venerable sir, the conversation that we were just now having.

original: Nesā, bhante, kathā bhagavato dullabhā bhavissati pacchāpi savanāya.
analyzed: na isā bhante kathā bhagavataḥ dullabhā bhavissati pacchā api savanāya
translated: It will not be hard for the Blessed One to hear it again.

original: Yadāhaṁ, bhante, imaṁ parisaṁ anupasaṅkanto homi athāyaṁ parisā anekavihitaṁ tiracchānakathaṁ kathentī nisinnā hoti;
analyzed: yat āha bhante imam parisam an upasaṅkantaḥ homi atha ayam parisā aneka vihitam tiracchāna katham kathentī nisinnā hoti
translated: When I was not present, venerable sir, this assembly was sitting talking various kinds of talk unworthy of arahants.

original: yadā ca kho ahaṁ, bhante, imaṁ parisaṁ upasaṅkanto homi athāyaṁ parisā mamaññeva mukhaṁ ullokentī nisinnā hoti:
analyzed: yadā ca kho aha bhante imam parisam upasaṅkantaḥ homi atha ayam parisā mamaññā iva mukham ullokentī nisinnā hoti
translated: But when I was present, venerable sir, this assembly was sitting looking up at my face, thinking:

original: ‘yaṁ no samaṇo udāyī dhammaṁ bhāsissati taṁ sossāmā’ti;
analyzed: yam naḥ samaṇaḥ udāyī dhammam bhāsissati tam sossāma ati
translated: ‘Whatever the venerable Udayin will teach us, that we will take up.’

original: yadā pana, bhante, bhagavā imaṁ parisaṁ upasaṅkanto hoti athāhañceva ayañca parisā bhagavato mukhaṁ ullokentā nisinnā homa:
analyzed: yadā pana bhante bhagavā imam parisam upasaṅkantaḥ hoti atha aham ca iva ayam ca parisā bhagavataḥ mukham nisinnā
translated: But when the Blessed One is present, venerable sir, both I and this assembly are sitting looking up at the Blessed One’s face, thinking:

original: ‘yaṁ no bhagavā dhammaṁ bhāsissati taṁ sossāmā’”ti.
analyzed: yam naḥ bhagavā dhammam bhāsissati tam sossāma ati
translated: ‘Whatever the Blessed One will teach us, that we will take up.’”

original: “Tenahudāyi, taṁyevettha paṭibhātu yathā maṁ paṭibhāseyyā”ti.
analyzed: tenahudāyi tayā iva itthā paṭibhātu yathā mama paṭibhāseyya ati
translated: “Well then, Udāyī, let’s just discuss this.”

original: “Purimāni, bhante, divasāni purimatarāni sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ🔽paṭijānamāno ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
analyzed: purimāni bhante divasāni purimatarāni sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassana  paṭijānamāno carataḥ ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: “In the past, Venerable Sir, when the Buddha claimed to be all-knowing and all-seeing,🔽and to have uninterrupted knowledge and vision,

original: So mayā pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
analyzed: saḥ mayā pubbantam ārabbha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ aññena aññam paṭicari bahiddhā katham apanāmesi kopam ca dosam ca appaccayam ca pātvā akāsi
translated: he evaded my questions, talked about something else, and got annoyed, nasty, and rude.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁyeva ārabbha sati udapādi:
analyzed: tassa bhante bhagavantayā iva ārabbha sati udapādi
translated: But then I remembered the Buddha and thought,

original: ‘aho nūna bhagavā, aho nūna sugato. Yo imesaṁ dhammānaṁ sukusalo’”ti.
analyzed: aho nūna bhagavā aho nūna sugataḥ yaḥ imesam dhammānam su kusalaḥ ti
translated: ‘Oh, the Buddha is so skilled in these matters!’”

original: “Ko pana so, udāyi, sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānamāno ‘carato
analyzed: kaḥ pana saḥ udāyi sabbaññū sabba dassāvī aparisesam ñāṇa dassanam paṭijānamāno carataḥ
translated: “But who is this all-knowing and all-seeing one, Udāyī, who claims to have uninterrupted knowledge and vision,

original: ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti,
analyzed: ca me tiṭṭhataḥ ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satatam samitam ñāṇa dassanam paccupaṭṭhitanti
translated: whether I’m awake or asleep, my knowledge and insight are constantly and continuously present to me.’

original: yo tayā pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññenaññaṁ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṁ
analyzed: yaḥ tayā pubbantam ārabbha pañham puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ aññena aññam paṭicari bahiddhā
translated: When asked a question about the past, you sidestepped the question and gave a lengthy teaching on other topics.

original: apanāmesi kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsī”ti?
analyzed: apanāmesi kopam ca dosañca appaccayañca pātvā akāsi iti
translated: You got angry, hostile, and resentful, and you disparaged, insulted, and humiliated me.”

original: “Nigaṇṭho, bhante, nāṭaputto”ti.
analyzed: nigaṇṭhaḥ bhante nāṭa putto ti
translated: “Sir, it was the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.”

original: “Yo kho, udāyi, anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyya, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi🔽jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussareyya, so vā maṁ🔽pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyya, taṁ vāhaṁ pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyyaṁ;
analyzed: yaḥ kho udāyi aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussareyya sā iyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi  jātiyo pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussareyya saḥ vā ma  pubbantam ārabbha pañham puccheyya tam vā aham pubbantam ārabbha pañham puccheyya
translated: “Udāyī, if someone were to recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details,🔽and if they were to ask me a question about the past, or if I were to ask them a question about the past,

original: so vā me pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya, tassa vāhaṁ pubbantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ vā me pubbantam ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam ārādheyya tassa vā aham pubbantam ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam ārādheyya
translated: and if they were to satisfy me with their answer, or if I were to satisfy them with my answer,

original: Yo kho, udāyi, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passeyya cavamāne
analyzed: yaḥ kho udāyi dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passeyya cavamāne
translated: If someone were to see beings passing away and being reborn …

original: upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyya,🔽so vā maṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyya, taṁ vāhaṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhaṁ puccheyyaṁ;
analyzed: upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajāneyya  saḥ vā mama aparantam ārabbha pañham puccheyya tam vā aham aparantam ārabbha pañham puccheyya
translated: and understanding how beings fare in accordance with their kamma,🔽then he could ask me about the future, and I could ask him about the future.

original: so vā me aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya, tassa vāhaṁ aparantaṁ ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ vā me aparantam ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam ārādheyya tassa vā aham aparantam ārabbha pañhassa veyyākaraṇena cittam ārādheyya
translated: He could satisfy my mind with his answers to my questions about the future, or I could satisfy his mind with my answers to his questions about the future.

original: Api ca, udāyi, tiṭṭhatu pubbanto, tiṭṭhatu aparanto.
analyzed: api ca udāyi tiṭṭhatu pubba antaḥ tiṭṭhatu apara antaḥ
translated: But let the past and future be.

original: Dhammaṁ te desessāmi—
analyzed: dhammam te desessāmi
translated: I will teach you the Dhamma:

original: imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati;
analyzed: imasmin sati idam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati
translated: ‘When this exists, that is; due to the arising of this, that arises.

original: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: imasmin asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti
translated: When this doesn’t exist, that is not; due to the cessation of this, that ceases.’”

original: “Ahañhi, bhante, yāvatakampi me iminā attabhāvena paccanubhūtaṁ tampi nappahomi sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anussarituṁ,
analyzed: aham hi bhante yāvatakam pi me iminā atta bhāvena paccanubhūtam tam pi na appahomi sa ākāram sa uddesam anussaritu
translated: “Venerable Sir, I can’t even remember what I’ve experienced in this very life, so how could I remember my many kinds of past lives, with their aspects and particulars?

original: kuto panāhaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissāmi, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarissāmi, seyyathāpi bhagavā?
analyzed: kutas pana aham aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissāmi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarissāmi seyyathā api bhagavā
translated: How could I remember my many kinds of past lives, with their aspects and particulars, as the Buddha does?

original: Ahañhi, bhante, etarahi paṁsupisācakampi na passāmi,🔽kuto panāhaṁ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passissāmi cavamāne
analyzed: ahan hi bhante etarahi pasupisācakam pi na passāmi  kutas pana aham dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passissāmi cavamāne
translated: Venerable Sir, I can’t even see a worm in my feces,

original: upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānissāmi, seyyathāpi bhagavā?
analyzed: upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānissāmi seyyathā api bhagavā
translated: so how could I see beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations—understanding how beings fare in accordance with their kamma, as the Buddha does?

original: Yaṁ pana maṁ, bhante, bhagavā evamāha:
analyzed: yam pana ma bhante bhagavān evam āha
translated: But, Sir, when the Buddha says this to me,

original: ‘api ca, udāyi, tiṭṭhatu pubbanto, tiṭṭhatu aparanto;
analyzed: api ca udāyi tiṭṭhatu pubba antaḥ tiṭṭhatu apara antaḥ
translated: ‘Well, Udāyī, let the past alone, and the future.

original: dhammaṁ te desessāmi—
analyzed: dhammam te desessāmi
translated: I’ll teach you the Dhamma:

original: imasmiṁ sati idaṁ hoti, imassuppādā idaṁ uppajjati;
analyzed: imasmin sati idam hoti imassa uppādā idam uppajjati
translated: ‘When this exists, that comes to be; from the arising of this, that arises.

original: imasmiṁ asati idaṁ na hoti, imassa nirodhā idaṁ nirujjhatī’ti tañca pana me bhiyyoso mattāya na pakkhāyati.
analyzed: imasmin asati idam na hoti imassa nirodhā idam nirujjhati iti tat ca pana me bhiyyosaḥ mattāya na pakkhāyati
translated: When this doesn’t exist, that doesn’t come to be; from the cessation of this, that ceases.’ But I’m not satisfied with just that.

original: Appeva nāmāhaṁ, bhante, sake ācariyake bhagavato cittaṁ ārādheyyaṁ pañhassa veyyākaraṇenā”ti.
analyzed: appa iva nāma āha bhante sake ācariyake bhagavato cittam ārādheyyam pañhassa veyyākaraṇena ati
translated: Sir, I’d like to please the Buddha’s mind by answering his question.”

original: “Kinti pana te, udāyi, sake ācariyake hotī”ti?
analyzed: kinti pana te udāyi sake ācariyake hoti iti
translated: “But what is it that you have learned from your own teachers?”

original: “Amhākaṁ, bhante, sake ācariyake evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: bhante sake ācariyake evam hoti
translated: “Sir, we say this:

original: ‘ayaṁ paramo vaṇṇo, ayaṁ paramo vaṇṇo’”ti.🔽“Yaṁ pana te etaṁ, udāyi, sake ācariyake evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: ayam paramaḥ vaṇṇaḥ ayam paramaḥ vaṇṇo ti  yam pana te ete udāyi sake ācariyake evam hoti
translated: ‘This is the ultimate beauty. This is the ultimate beauty.’”

original: ‘ayaṁ paramo vaṇṇo, ayaṁ paramo vaṇṇo’ti, katamo so paramo vaṇṇo”ti?

translated: “Here, Venerable Sir, someone gives up killing living creatures and abstains from killing living creatures, gives up taking what is not given and abstains from taking what is not given, gives up sexual activity and abstains from sexual activity, gives up lying and abstains from lying, or they undertake and observe one or another of the various forms of ascetic practice.

original: Ayaṁ kho sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho sā bhante ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: This is the way to realise a completely pleasant world.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi
translated: “What do you think, Udāyī,

original: yasmiṁ samaye pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti?
analyzed: yasmin samaye pāṇa atipātam pahāya pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti ekanta sukhī vā tasmin samaye attā hoti sukha dukkhī vā ati
translated: when someone gives up killing living creatures and abstains from killing living creatures, is their self completely happy or both happy and unhappy?”

original: “Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī bhante
translated: “Unhappy, Venerable Sir.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi
translated: “What do you think, Udayin?

original: yasmiṁ samaye adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti?
analyzed: yasmin samaye adinnādānam pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirataḥ hoti ekanta sukhī vā tasmin samaye attā hoti sukha dukkhī vā ati
translated: When someone gives up stealing and refrains from stealing, is their self at that time happy or suffering?”

original: “Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī bhante
translated: “Suffering, Sir.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi, yasmiṁ samaye kāmesumicchācāraṁ pahāya kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti?
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi yasmin samaye kāmesum icchā ācāram pahāya kāmesum icchā ācārā paṭivirataḥ hoti ekanta sukhī vā tasmin samaye attā hoti sukha dukkhī vā ati
translated: “When someone gives up sexual misconduct and refrains from sexual misconduct, is their self at that time happy or suffering?”

original: “Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī bhante
translated: “Suffering, Sir.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi, yasmiṁ samaye musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti?
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi yasmin samaye musāvādam pahāya musāvādā paṭivirataḥ hoti ekanta sukhī vā tasmin samaye attā hoti sukha dukkhī vā ati
translated: “When someone gives up lying and refrains from lying, is their self at that time happy or suffering?”

original: “Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī bhante
translated: “Suffering, Sir.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi
translated: “What do you think, Udayin?

original: yasmiṁ samaye aññataraṁ tapoguṇaṁ samādāya vattati, ekantasukhī vā tasmiṁ samaye attā hoti sukhadukkhī vā”ti?
analyzed: yasmin samaye aññataram tapo guṇam samādāya vattati ekanta sukhī vā tasmin samaye attā hoti sukha dukkhī vā ati
translated: When someone takes up a certain kind of ascetic practice, is their self at that time happy or suffering?”

original: “Sukhadukkhī, bhante”.
analyzed: sukha dukkhī bhante
translated: “Suffering, Sir.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, udāyi,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi udāyi
translated: “What do you think, Udayin?

original: api nu kho vokiṇṇasukhadukkhaṁ paṭipadaṁ āgamma ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hotī”ti?
analyzed: api nu kho vokiṇṇa sukha dukkham paṭipadam āgamma ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hoti iti
translated: Is it possible to make the state of complete happiness real by practicing a path that is mixed with suffering and happiness?”

original: “Acchidaṁ bhagavā kathaṁ, acchidaṁ sugato kathan”ti.
analyzed: acchidam bhagavā acchidam sugataḥ
translated: “The Buddha has cut off the discussion, the one good at discussion has cut off the discussion.”

original: “Kiṁ pana tvaṁ, udāyi, vadesi:
analyzed: kim pana tvam udāyi vadesi
translated: “But, Udāyī, what do you mean by saying

original: ‘acchidaṁ bhagavā kathaṁ, acchidaṁ sugato kathan’”ti?
analyzed: acchidam bhagavā acchidam sugataḥ
translated: that the Buddha has cut off the discussion, the one good at discussion has cut off the discussion?”

original: “Amhākaṁ, bhante, sake ācariyake evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: bhante sake ācariyake evam hoti
translated: “Sir, in our own teachers’ tradition it is said

original: ‘atthi ekantasukho loko, atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā’ti.
analyzed: atthi ekanta sukhaḥ lokaḥ atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: that there is a world of complete happiness, and that there is a practice that leads to the realization of a world of complete happiness.

original: Te mayaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā sake ācariyake samanuyuñjiyamānā samanuggāhiyamānā samanubhāsiyamānā rittā tucchā aparaddhā”ti.
analyzed: te bhante bhagavatā sake ācariyake samanuyuñjiyamānā samanuggāhiyamānā samanubhāsiyamānā rittā tucchā aparaddhā ati
translated: But when we were questioned, pressed, and cross-examined by the Buddha, we were at a loss, without an answer, and failed.”

original: “Kiṁ pana, bhante, atthi ekantasukho loko, atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti?
analyzed: kim pana bhante atthi ekanta sukhaḥ lokaḥ atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: “But, Sir, is there a world of complete happiness, and is there a practice that leads to the realization of a world of complete happiness?”

original: “Atthi kho, udāyi, ekantasukho loko, atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: atthi kho udāyi ekanta sukhaḥ lokaḥ atthi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: “There is, Udayin, a completely pleasant world. There is a way to the realization of a completely pleasant world.”

original: “Katamā pana sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti?
analyzed: katamā pana sā bhante ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: “But, venerable sir, what is that way to the realization of a completely pleasant world?”

original: “Idhudāyi, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;🔽vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati;
analyzed: idhudāyi bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati  vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā pe dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, Udayin, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.🔽With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: pītiyā ca virāgā …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati—
analyzed: pītiyā ca virāgā pe tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the fading away as well of rapture, he abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling pleasure with the body, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’

original: ayaṁ kho sā, udāyi, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho sā udāyi ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: This is the way to the realization of a completely pleasant world.”

original: “Na kho sā, bhante, ākāravatī paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya, sacchikato hissa, bhante, ettāvatā ekantasukho loko hotī”ti.
analyzed: na kho sā bhante ākāravatī paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya sacchikataḥ hissa bhante ettāvatā ekanta sukhaḥ lokaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Venerable sir, that is not the way to the realization of a completely pleasant world. For as far as that extends, venerable sir, a completely pleasant world has been realized.”

original: “Na khvāssa, udāyi, ettāvatā ekantasukho loko sacchikato hoti;
analyzed: na khvā assa udāyi ettāvatā ekanta sukhaḥ loko sacchikataḥ hoti
translated: “Udayin, a completely pleasant world has not been realized as far as that extends.

original: ākāravatī tveva sā paṭipadā ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: ākāravatī tu eva sā paṭipadā ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: But the way that has the aspect of pleasure is for the realization of the world of absolute pleasure.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā unnādinī uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahosi:
analyzed: evam vutte sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā unnādinī uccāsadda mahāsaddā ahosi
translated: When this was said, Sakuludayin’s assembly made an uproar, shouting:

original: “ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā, ettha mayaṁ anassāma sācariyakā.
analyzed: ettha mayam anassāma sācariyakāḥ ettha mayam anassāma sācariyakā
translated: “We’re lost, along with our teacher! We’re lost, along with our teacher!

original: Na mayaṁ ito bhiyyo uttaritaraṁ pajānāmā”ti.
analyzed: na mayam itas bhiyyas uttaritaram pajānāma ati
translated: We don’t know anything beyond this!”

original: Atha kho sakuludāyī paribbājako te paribbājake appasadde katvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho sakuludāyī paribbājakaḥ te paribbājake appasadde katvā bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then Sakuludayin quieted his assembly and said to the Buddha,

original: “kittāvatā panāssa, bhante, ekantasukho loko sacchikato hotī”ti?
analyzed: kittāvatā pana assa bhante ekanta sukhaḥ loko sacchikataḥ hoti iti
translated: “But how, Sir, is the world of absolute pleasure realized?”

original: “Idhudāyi, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ … upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idhudāyi bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā pe catuttham jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, Udāyī, a monk, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous passing away of joy and displeasure, enters and remains in the fourth jhāna, neither painful nor pleasant, which has purification of mindfulness by equanimity.

original: Yā tā devatā ekantasukhaṁ lokaṁ upapannā tāhi devatāhi saddhiṁ santiṭṭhati sallapati sākacchaṁ samāpajjati.
analyzed: yāḥ tāḥ devatāḥ ekanta sukham lokam upapannā tāhi devatāhi saddhim santiṭṭhati sallapati sākaccham samāpajjati
translated: He remains in companionship with those deities who have arisen in a world of absolute pleasure. He converses with them and engages in discussions.

original: Ettāvatā khvāssa, udāyi, ekantasukho loko sacchikato hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā khvā assa udāyi ekanta sukhaḥ lokaḥ sacchikataḥ hoti iti
translated: It’s in this way, Udāyī, that the world of absolute pleasure is realized.”

original: “Etassa nūna, bhante, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti?
analyzed: etassa nūna bhante ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyam caranti iti
translated: “Venerable sir, is it for the sake of realizing the world of complete happiness that the bhikkhus live the spiritual life under the Blessed One?”

original: “Na kho, udāyi, ekantasukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
analyzed: na kho udāyi ekanta sukhassa lokassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti
translated: “No, Udayin, it is not for the sake of realizing the world of complete happiness that the bhikkhus live the spiritual life under me.

original: Atthi kho, udāyi, aññeva dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca, yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti.
analyzed: atthi kho udāyi aññā eva dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesam sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti iti
translated: There are other things higher and more sublime than that, for the sake of realizing which the bhikkhus live the spiritual life under me.”

original: “Katame pana te, bhante, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti?
analyzed: katame pana te bhante dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesam sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū bhagavati brahmacariyam caranti iti
translated: “What are those other things, venerable sir, higher and more sublime than that, for the sake of realizing which the bhikkhus live the spiritual life under the Blessed One?”

original: “Idhudāyi, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā …pe…
analyzed: idh udāyi tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā pe
translated: “Here, Udayin, a Tathagata appears in the world, arahant, perfectly enlightened, accomplished in true knowledge and conduct, fortunate, knower of the world, unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed, teacher of devas and humans, the Enlightened One, the Blessed One.

original: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: Having abandoned these five hindrances, defilements of the mind that weaken wisdom,

original: vivicceva kāmehi …pe… paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vivicca iva kāmehi pe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, he enters and dwells in the first jhāna …

original: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho udāyi dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti
translated: This is a further Dhamma …

original: Puna caparaṁ, udāyi, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā … dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: puna caparaḥ udāyī bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā dutiyam jhānam
translated: Again, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and dwells in the second jhāna …

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam
translated: the third jhāna …

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: the fourth jhāna.

original: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho udāyi dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti
translated: This is a further Dhamma …

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati sa iyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, i.e. one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion, ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.🔽So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho udāyi dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti  saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: This, too, is a quality because of which monks lead the holy life under me.🔽“When his concentrated mind is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.🔽He sees — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma: ‘These beings — who were endowed with bad conduct of body, speech, and mind, who reviled the noble ones, held wrong views and undertook actions under the influence of wrong views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the plane of deprivation, the bad destination, the lower realms, in hell.

original: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate pe yathā kamma upage satte pajānāti
translated: But these beings — who were endowed with good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not revile the noble ones, who held right views and undertook actions under the influence of right views — with the break-up of the body, after death, have re-appeared in the good destinations, in the heavenly world.’ Thus — by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human — he sees beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma.

original: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho udāyi dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti
translated: This, too, is a quality because of which monks lead the holy life under me.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind was purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti …pe… ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti … ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti pe ayam dukkha nirodho ti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understood as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti … ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti … ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ime āsavā iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ uti ayam āsava nirodhaḥ uti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understood as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understood as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: As he understood this, his mind was liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it was liberated there came the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understood: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Ayampi kho, udāyi, dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ caranti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho udāyi dhammo uttaritaro ca paṇītataro ca yassa sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti
translated: This is a further thing that is higher and more sublime than those, for the sake of which monks lead the holy life under me.

original: Ime kho, udāyi, dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesaṁ sacchikiriyāhetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyaṁ carantī”ti.
analyzed: ime kho udāyi dhammā uttaritarā ca paṇītatarā ca yesam sacchikiriyā hetu bhikkhū mayi brahmacariyam caranti iti
translated: These are those things that are higher and more sublime than those, for the sake of which monks lead the holy life under me.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyī paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte sa kula udāyī paribbājakaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the wanderer Sakuludayin said to the Blessed One:

original: “abhikkantaṁ, bhante, abhikkantaṁ, bhante.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: abhikkanta bhante abhikkanta bhante  sā iyyathā api bhante nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent!

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,

original: evamevaṁ bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam evam bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: in the same way has Master Gotama—through many lines of reasoning—made the Dhamma clear.

original: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
analyzed: esā aha bhante bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca
translated: I go to Master Gotama for refuge, to the Dhamma, and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: Labheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṁ, labheyyaṁ upasampadan”ti.
analyzed: labheyya āha bhante bhagavato santike pabbajja labheyyam upasampadanti
translated: “Venerable Sir, if it is the right time for me to go forth and be fully admitted into the monastic life, may I receive the going forth and full admission in the Buddha’s presence.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ etadavocuṁ:
analyzed: evam vutte sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyim paribbājakam etat avocuḥ
translated: When this was said, the wanderers of other religions said to Sakuludāyī,

original: “mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ cari;
analyzed: mā bhavaḥ samaṇe gotame brahmacariyam cari
translated: “Don’t practice the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama,

original: mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, ācariyo hutvā antevāsīvāsaṁ vasi.
analyzed: mā bhavaḥ udāyi hutvā antevāsī vāsam vasi
translated: don’t live as a student under a teacher.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma udakamaṇiko hutvā udañcaniko assa, evaṁ sampadamidaṁ bhoto udāyissa bhavissati.
analyzed: sā iyyathā api nāma udaka maṇikaḥ hutvā assa evam sampadam idam bhoto udāyissa bhavissati
translated: It would be just like a water-pot that has been thrown away, broken, and discarded.

original: Mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, samaṇe gotame brahmacariyaṁ cari;
analyzed: mā bhavaḥ samaṇe gotame brahmacariyam cari
translated: Don’t practice the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama,

original: mā bhavaṁ, udāyi, ācariyo hutvā antevāsīvāsaṁ vasī”ti.
analyzed: mā bhava udāyi hutvā antevāsī vāsam vasi iti
translated: don’t live as a student under a teacher.”

original: Iti hidaṁ sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyiṁ paribbājakaṁ antarāyamakāsi bhagavati brahmacariyeti.
analyzed: iti hi idam sakuludāyissa paribbājakassa parisā sakuludāyim paribbājakam antarāyam akāsi bhagavati brahmacariyā iti
translated: In this way the assembly of wanderers prevented Sakuludāyī from practicing the spiritual life under the Buddha.

original: Cūḷasakuludāyisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: cūḷasakuludāyisuttam niṭṭhitam navama
translated: The shorter discourse with Sakuludāyī is finished.
